title: Analyzing protein intermediate interactions in living E. coli cells using site-specific photo-crosslinking combined with chemical crosslinking
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Cell growth and expression of the target proteins
Timing: 1 day
In this step (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1],step 1), the cells for the crosslinking analysis were grown, induced for the expression of the target proteins (LptD and BepA) from the plasmids, and harvested; the chromosomal BamA is constitutively expressed.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2542-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Workflow for site-specific in vivo photo-crosslinking combined with BMB-crosslinking
Inoculate a small amount of glycerol cell stock of RM3655/pNB91/pEVOL-pBpF carrying pRM829 or pRM831 into 1.5 mL of L medium supplemented with 0.4% (w/v) Glucose, 50 μg/mL Amp, 20 μg/mL Cm, and 50 μg/mL Spc in a sterile test tube.
Shake it overnight (≈16 h) at 30°C.
Inoculate 50 μL of the overnight culture into 5 mL of L medium supplemented with 50 μg/mL Amp, 20 μg/mL Cm, 50 μg/mL Spc, 0.5 mM pBPA, and 0.02% arabinose.
Shake at 30°C for 105 min until the optical density reached ≈0.16 (corresponding to about 1.5 × 108 cells/mL) with TAITEC OD Monitor.
Note: Arabinose is included to induce the expression of the evolved aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase/suppressor tRNA pair from pEVOL-pBpF.
Add 5 μL of 1 M IPTG in MilliQ H2O (final concentration 1 mM) to express LptD and BepA, and shake for 3 h at 30°C. The final optical density of the cultures after induction would be ≈0.8–0.85 (corresponding to about 7.5–8.0 × 108 cells/mL) with TAITEC OD Monitor.
Put test tubes on ice to cool the cultures.
BMB-crosslinking
Timing: 2 h
In this step (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1], step 2), cells expressing the target protein are treated with BMB to crosslink the two proteins (LptD and BamA).

Take an appropriate volume of the culture to a 5 mL centrifuge tube (Take 5 mL when final turbidity is ≈0.8 with TAITEC OD Monitor, which corresponds to about 7.5 × 108 cells/mL).
Centrifuge the tube (2,300 × g for 5 min at 4°C) and discard the supernatant.
Suspend the cells in 500 μL of Phosphate Buffer.
Centrifuged the tube (2,300 × g for 5 min at 4°C) and discard the supernatant.
Suspend the cells in 500 μL of Phosphate Buffer.
Add 10 μL of 100 mM TCEP-HCl (Tris(2-carboxyethyl)phosphine Hydrochloride dissolved in MilliQ H2O) at a final concentration of 2 mM.
Mix vigorously at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 20 min using High Speed Mixer CM-1000 (EYELA) to reduce the introduced Cys residues in LptD and BamA.
Critical: This step is important to make the Cys residues for BMB-crosslinking in a reduced form.
Centrifuge the tube (2,300 × g for 5 min at 4°C) and discard the supernatant.
Suspend the cells in 500 μL of Phosphate Buffer.
Centrifuge the tube (2,300 × g for 5 min at 4°C) and discard the supernatant.
Suspend the cells in 500 μL of Phosphate Buffer.
Divide the solution into 125 μL portions in four 1.5 mL tubes. Two tubes are used for the BMB reaction and the rest for the DMSO control reaction.
Add 3.1 μL of DMSO (control) or 20 mM BMB in DMSO (final concentration 0.5 mM).
Mix vigorously at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 40 min with High Speed Mixer CM-1000.
Add 12.5 μL of 100 mM L-Cysteine (final concentration 10 mM), and mix well.
Note: L-Cysteine quenches BMB and stops the crosslinking reaction.
Put the samples on ice for several minutes.
Combine the two separate BMB-treated and -untreated solutions into one tube, respectively.
pBPA mediated in vivo photo-crosslinking
Timing: 2 h

After the BMB-crosslinking, irradiate the cells with UV light to form pBPA-crosslinking and ternary crosslinked complexes (BamA-LptD-BepA; Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1], step 3).
Put a 150 μL portion of the cultures on Split Petri Dish 4 Sections (VWR) (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2542-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Detailed operations for in vivo photo-crosslinking experiments
(A) How to put the culture medium on Split Petri Dish 4 Sections (step 24).
(B) UV irradiation using B100-AP (step 25).
Alternatives: The use of the above special dish enables simultaneous UV-irradiation to 4 differrent smaples without cross-contamination, but a normal petri dish can be used instead.
Irradiate the cells with UV light (365 nm, 22 mW/cm2 at a distance of 5 cm) for 30 min at 4°C using B100-AP (UVP; Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B). Skip this step if UV irradiation was not performed (for the control [no UV sample]).
Note: UV irradiation for a long period would heat the cell culture and cause the denaturation of cellular proteins. Therefore, conducting UV-irradiation of the cells in the cold room is recommended.
After mixing the cultures by pipetting, take 100 μL and rapidly and thoroughly mix with 100 μL of 10% (v/v) TCA solution to denature proteins.
Put the tubes on ice for over 30 min.
Centrifuge the tube (20,400 × g for 5 min at 4°C) and discard the supernatant.
Add 600 μL of acetone to the pellet, and then sonicate with a desk-top bath sonicator and vortex to wash the protein precipitates.
Centrifuge the tube (20,400 × g for 5 min at 4°C) again and discard the supernatant.
Air-dry the pellets at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Note: The pellets can be stably stored at least for a month at −25°C.
Purification and detection of crosslinked products
Timing: 2 days

In this step (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1], step 4), the crosslinked product was isolated and concentrated by affinity isolation using the His10-tag fused to the target protein, because the cellular levels of the ternary crosslinked products are often too low to be detected by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting when total cell lysates are used. The purified proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and Immunoblotting.
Add 99 μL of SDS buffer containing of 12.5 mM NEM (N-ethylmaleimide) to the pellet.
Note: NEM forms a covalent bond with free Cys residues and blocks the disulfide bond formation during subsequent processes.
Dissolve pellets by sonication, vortexing for 5 min and heating at 98°C for 5 min.
Then, put 57 μL of the SDS-solubilized proteins into a 2 mL tube containing 1,800 μL of Triton Buffer.
Mix by vortexing.
Centrifuge the tube (9,100 × g for 10 min at 4°C).
Transfer 1,800 μL of the supernatants to a new 2 mL tube.
Add 30 μL of Ni-NTA Agarose (QIAGEN) suspended in 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.1).
Note: Be careful not to take the pellets.
Note: Before use, wash Ni-NTA agarose with 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.1) as described below.
Pipet 100 μL of 50% Ni-NTA agarose suspension in 30% EtOH into a 1.5 mL tube containing 1 mL of 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.1). Centrifuge the tube (9,100 × g for 20 s at 4°C), discard the supernatants, and suspend the Ni-NTA agarose in 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.1) by adding 50 μL of 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.1) and tapping.
Gently mix the samples overnight (12–16 h) at 4°C with vertical rotation of tubes at approximately 10 rpm.
Centrifuge the tubes (9,100 × g for 20 s at 4°C), discard the supernatants.
Wash the pellets by adding 1,000 μL of Triton Buffer and vortexing.

After centrifugation (9,100 × g for 20 s at 4°C), discard the supernatants.
Wash the pellets again by adding 1,000 μL of 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.1) and vortexing.
Centrifuge the tube (9,100 × g for 20 s at 4°C), and completely discard the supernatants.
Add 80 μL of SDS Sample Buffer and mix well by tapping to elute the proteins (the His10-tagged proteins are eluted by the SDS sample buffer as 2-mercaptoethanol reduces Ni in this buffer).
Heat the sample at 98°C for 5 min.
Note: Because BMB is an irreversible maleimide crosslinker, the BMB crosslinks are not cleaved by treatment with the 2-mercaptoethanol reducing agent, unlike disulfide bonds.
Centrifuge the tube (9,100 × g for 20 s at room temperature (20°C–25°C)) and collect the supernatant containing eluted proteins.
Separate the purified proteins by 7.5% Laemmli SDS-PAGE using a standard protocol.
Transfer the separated proteins on to PVDF (0.45 μm) membrane using a standard semi-dry blotting procedure.
Incubate the PVDF membrane in the BLOTTO solution for 30 min at 42°C for blocking.
Wash the PVDF membrane with PBS-Tween Buffer.
Incubate the PVDF membranes in Can Get Signal Solution 1 (TOYOBO) and primary antibody (anti-BepA antibody (1:10000 dilution) or anti-BamA antibody (1:20000 dilution)) at room temperature (20°C–25°C) overnight with gentle shaking (12–14 h).
Critical: The time required for primary antibody treatment can often be shortened to a few hours. However, the intensity of the crosslinked bands was considerably weakened. Therefore, an overnight primary antibody treatment is strongly recommended to obtain clear results.
Note: Can Get Signal is a solution that improves the sensitivity and specificity in detection by immunoblotting.
Wash the PVDF membranes three times for 5–10 min with PBS-Tween buffer with gentle shaking.

Incubate the PVDF membranes in Can Get Signal Solution 2 (TOYOBO) with a secondary antibody (Goat Anti-Rabbit IgG (H + L)-HRP Conjugate; 1:5000 dilution) for 1 h with gentle shaking at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Wash the PVDF membranes three times for 5–10 min with PBS-Tween buffer with gentle shaking.
Immerse the PVDF membrane in ECL prime solution for 1 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Detect the chemiluminescence signals using the LAS4000 mini lumino-image analyzer.
